Expectation1: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation1: The pantry is stocked with kosher ingredients, and alternative snacks are readily available.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I glance at the clock as I finish my last errand, my stomach rumbling. The polling station closes in two hours, and I haven’t eaten since morning. My mind races through the options: I could stop at the café on the corner, but I know they don’t serve kosher food. At home, the pantry is stocked with everything I need—matzah, tuna, even some leftover kugel. But if I go home to eat, I might not make it back to the polling station in time. My community expects me to uphold kosher laws, and I feel the weight of that responsibility. At the same time, voting is not just a right but a duty, and I promised myself I’d have my say in this election. My hands tremble as I weigh the expectations—my faith, my civic responsibility. The minutes tick by, and I stand on the sidewalk, torn between the demands of my heritage and my role as a citizen, feeling the pressure build inside me.
